avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from early morning above approximately 2000 m, in particular along the border with France. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size in the course of the day. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The fresh snow of the last few days and very particularly the wind slabs can be released easily or naturally. In some places avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size, in particular along the border with France.

As a consequence of warming small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads especially between approximately 2700 and 3000 m, caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Whumpfing sounds are a clear indication.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
25 to 40 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2200 m rain has fallen. The westerly wind has transported the new snow significantly. These weather conditions gave rise to unfavourable bonding of the old snowpack in some places in particular along the border with France below approximately 2500 m.
The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations. In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2000 m, depending on the infuence of the wind.

tendency.highlights: Slight decrease in avalanche danger as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from early morning above approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally as the day progresses. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on very steep slopes.
More mostly small dry and moist avalanches are possible, in particular at the base of rock walls, and in extremely steep terrain.

snowpackStructure.comment:
10 to 25 cm of snow fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. The westerly wind has transported the new snow.
The weather conditions on Thursday gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.
The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow.
In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2000 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.

tendency.highlights: Slight decrease in avalanche danger as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.

avalancheActivity.comment: 2 to 10 cm of snow will fall from early morning above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes mostly shallow wind slabs will form. Caution is to be exercised on extremely steep slopes, especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example, in particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 2 (moderate). In these regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in extremely steep terrain at intermediate and high altitudes.

regions.name: B - VALLI DI GRESSONEY, AYAS, CHAMPORCHER

snowpackStructure.comment:
5 to 10 cm of snow fell in the last three days above approximately 1800 m.
The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations. In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. On steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m a little snow is lying. At low and intermediate altitudes from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
